Authors: Josephj Liam Humble, Xiang Meng, John Andrew Craft
Title:
Inter-species analysis of fish vitellogenin reveals
enrichment of specific amino acids correlates with reproductive
strategy.
Keywords:
Vitellogenin, Fish, Comparative Biology, Macroevolution,
Molecular Evolution, Reproduction, Benthic, Pelagic
Abstract:
Here we conduct a descriptive and explorative analysis of
association between VTG amino acid composition and reproductive strategy
across fish species. Fish egg nutrients are primarily provided by
vitellogenin (VTG), a large phosphoglycolipoprotein synthesized in the
maternal liver and incorporated into oocytes. Fish species typically
have multiple VTG paralogs classed as VTGA, VTGB and VTGC. During oocyte
maturation VTG is cleaved to form yolk proteins, which are selectively
depolymerized in pelagic fish. This creates a pool of free amino acids
(AA) that drives oocyte hydration enabling buoyancy. Presented here are
three full-length VTG sequences of the sand goby (Pomatoschistus
minutus) a benthic marine teleost and phylogenetic analysis classes them
VTGA, VTGB and VTGC. Interspecies sequence comparison shows alanine is
higher throughout the red seabream lipovitellin domains compared to sand
goby. Meta-analysis of VTG of the acanthopterygii clade reveals AA of
whole VTGs or specific domains correlate with reproductive strategy.
Amongst others, alanine enrichment is correlated with pelagic eggs and
serine enrichment is correlated with non-pelagic eggs (in lipovitellin
and Î²-component domains). Interparalogous analysis shows alanine and
serine levels in VTGA class correlate with that of VTGB. The results
reveal VTG domains fated to depolymerize to form the free AA pool in
pelagic fish are particularly enriched with alanine. These results imply
the dynamics of VTG composition relates to exploitation of novel
breeding strategies and considering the phylogeny of the teleost fish
implies the pelagic/benthic dichotomy of reproductive strategy has
evolved in tandem with VTG AA enrichment multiple independent
times.
